choices.text: Buboes can be seen in this disease
Caused by Chlamydia Trachomatis Serovars D-K
Groove sign of Greenblatt is pathognomonic in this disease
Incubation period is 3-30 days

questions.text: A man is referred to the STI clinic with the following painful inguinal lymphadenopathy. He gives a history of a small transient painless ulcer on his penis 5 weeks ago, which resolved on its own. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caused by Chlamydia Trachomatis Serovars D-K

 

Option B: Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars D-K

 

Explanation:

 

  • This image shows the pathognomonic groove sign of Greenblatt (Option C) which is suggestive of lymphogranuloma venereum. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1-L3.

  • In one-third of cases, a groove sign is visible. It describes the depression on either side of the inguinal ligament that is situated between the enlarged femoral and inguinal lymph nodes.

  • Following a painless genital ulcer, buboes, or painful masses of lymph nodes, can be seen. Usually, lymphogranuloma venereum exhibits this.

  • Incubation period is 3-30 days. There are three phases in it. (Option D)

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum:

Primary stage:

 

  • Starts with painless papules or transient ulcers that may go unnoticed at the inoculation site.

  • The conventional ulcer is solitary, shallow, unindurated, and may or may not be painful.

 

Secondary stage:

 

  • Appearance of tender femoral and/or inguinal lymphadenopathy develops 2â€“6 weeks later. Buboes or abscesses may develop from the nodes when they coalesce, and fistulae and sinus tracts may develop when they rupture. (Option A)


Tertiary stage:

 

  • Occurs several years later and is characterized by lymphatic obstruction and disfiguring conditions such as elephantiasis and Esthiomene.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, or L3, not serovars D-K, and presents with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy and may have a transient genital ulcer.

  • The groove sign is pathognomonic for LGV, and the incubation period ranges from 3 to 30 days.

 

Ref:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 30 Page no 30.18

choices.text: Lymphogranuloma venereum
Chancroid
Granuloma inguinale
Syphilis

questions.text: Esthiomene as shown in the image can occur in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymphogranuloma venereum

 

Option A: Lymphogranuloma venereum
 

  • A characteristic of lymphogranuloma venereum is Esthiomene.
  • Due to fibrosis and chronic inflammation, there is lymphatic obstruction in the tertiary stage of LGV.
  • This leads to genital lymphoedema, inflammation, ulceration, and chronic granulomatous fibrosis, which in turn causes Esthiomene in women.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Chancroid:

 

  • Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, presents with painful genital ulcers and tender suppurative regional lymphadenopathy. It does not typically progress to Esthiomene.


Option C. Granuloma inguinale (Donovanosis):

 

  • Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, granuloma inguinale is characterized by beefy red ulcers without lymphadenopathy. It is not associated with Esthiomene.


Option D. Syphilis:

 

  • Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, presents with different stages. Primary syphilis presents with a painless chancre, secondary syphilis can present with rash and generalized lymphadenopathy, and tertiary syphilis can cause gummas, aortitis, Tabes dorsalis, etc., but not Esthiomene.


Educational Objective:
 

  • The presence of Esthiomene is indicative of the chronic inflammatory and scarring process associated with Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), a sexually transmitted infection caused by certain serovars of Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 30 Page no 30.18

choices.text: Primary ulcer heals without scarring
It has an incubation period of 8 to 80 days
It has the potential for malignant transformation
Caused by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to Derma OPD with a painless and foul-smelling ulcer. On examination, there is no lymphadenopathy. The image below shows the microscopic analysis of a sample taken from a genital ulcer. Which of the following statements about this illness is FALSE?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary ulcer heals without scarring

 

Option A: Primary ulcer heals without scarring

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given image shows Donovan bodies, which points to a diagnosis of Granuloma inguinale.
  • The clinical picture of a painless, beefy red, foul-smelling ulcer with no lymphadenopathy is classical for Granuloma inguinale.
  • Granuloma inguinale is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis / Klebsiella granulomatis. (Option D)
  • The incubation period varies from 8-80 days, the average being 50 days. (Option B)
  • The primary ulcer, if left untreated, heals spontaneously with scarring, or persists and spreads. (Option A)
  • Untreated genital ulcers are followed by genital disfigurement and have the potential for malignant change. (Option C)
  • Donovan bodies refer to the Gram-negative rod-shaped or oval organisms that show bipolar staining or safety-pin appearance, present intracellularly in the cytoplasm of large mononuclear cells.
     

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Granuloma inguinale, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, and the primary ulcer, if left untreated, heals spontaneously with scarring, or persists and spreads.
     

Ref:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 30 Page no 30.25

choices.text: Pseudobubo seen
Pseudo Groove sign seen
Azithromycin is the first-line treatment
Causative organism is Leishmania Donovani

questions.text: Which of the following is FALSE about Donovanosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Causative organism is Leishmania Donovani

 

Option D: Causative organism is Leishmania Donovani

 

Explanation:

 

  • Pseudobubo refers to granulomatous lesions that may extend into subcutaneous tissue and mimic lymphadenopathy in Donovanosis. (Option A)
  • Like the groove sign of Greenblatt seen in lymphogranuloma venereum, a pseudo-groove sign is produced when these lesions are present above and below the inguinal ligament. (Option B)
  • The first-line treatment is azithromycin 1 g orally once weekly or 500 mg daily for 3 weeks.  (Option C)

 

In this condition, prolonged antibiotic therapy is required. Antibiotics must be given for 3-6 weeks and until the ulcer has completely healed. The second-line drugs are as follows:

 

  • Doxycycline 100 mg orally BD
  • Erythromycin base 500 mg orally QID
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole 160 mg/800 mg orally BD

 

Donovanosis / Granuloma inguinale is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis / Klebsiella granulomatis.

 

Leishmania donovani is Causative organism for Visceral leishmaniasis. (Option D)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The causative organism of Donovanosis is Klebsiella granulomatis, and not Leishmania donovani, which is responsible for visceral leishmaniasis.

 

Ref:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 30 Page no 30.24 30.25

choices.text: Green kit
Red kit
Blue kit
D White kit

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman has come down with painful lesions as shown below. She tells you that vesicles were present 5 days back over the same site and says that she is allergic to penicillin. On examination, she has bilateral tender lymphadenopathy. Which kit will you use to treat her?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Red kit

 

Option B: Red kit

 

  • The treatment of Genital Herpes involves antiviral therapy, which is typically provided in the red kit.

  • It contains acyclovir 400 mg tablets to be taken TDS for 7 days, which is effective against the herpes simplex virus.

 

Explanation:

 

  • The clinical picture of multiple, grouped painful ulcers with tender lymphadenopathy in this patient points to a diagnosis of herpes genitalis infection by HSV-2.

  • It is treated with a red kit. In herpetic genital ulcer disease, treatment of asymptomatic partners is not required.

  • The red kit or kit 5 is meant for genital ulcer disease - herpetic. It contains acyclovir 400 mg tablets to be taken TDS for 7 days.

  • Chancroid, which manifests as numerous, tender soft, painful ulcers, & bilateral lymphadenopathy is a close differential diagnosis.

  • Chancroid, on the other hand, lacks vesicles and has deeper ulcers with ragged, undermined edges.

  • Only when the patient presents with the primary chancre of syphilis is the patient's history of penicillin drug allergy relevant.

  • They would need to be treated with a blue kit in this situation rather than a white kit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The treatment of Genital Herpes involves antiviral therapy, which is typically provided in the red kit.

  • It contains acyclovir 400 mg tablets to be taken TDS for 7 days, which is effective against the herpes simplex virus.

 

Ref:  National Health Programs of India http://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/Syndromic%20Poster_REDUCED.pdf  Harrison's Principles Of Internal Medicine - 19th Edition Page no 880

choices.text: Haemophilus Ducreyi is causative organism
Azithromycin 1g oral stat is the first line of treatment
Kissing ulcers can be present
Concomitant ulcer is not seen in this condition

questions.text: A young woman presents with painful deep ulcers on her genitals 4 days after unprotected sexual intercourse as shown below. She also has painful unilateral lymphadenopathy with suppurating buboes. What is the FALSE statement regarding this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Concomitant ulcer is not seen in this condition

 

Option D: Concomitant ulcer is not seen in this condition

 

  • In Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, multiple painful ulcers can occur, including "kissing ulcers," and effective first-line treatment includes Azithromycin 1g orally as a single dose.
  • Concomitant genital ulcer is seen associated with Chancroid.

 

Explanation:

 

  • This patient has chancroid, which is evident by the painful, deep ulcers and tender lymphadenopathy.
  • The etiologic agent for chancroid is Haemophilus ducreyi. (Option A)
  • The incubation period is 3–10 days. The primary lesion starts as a painful papule that develops into painful, non-indurated ulcers with undermined edges after undergoing central necrosis.
  • Kissing ulcers due to autoinoculation may also be present. (Option C)
  • It is accompanied by painful lymphadenopathy, which develops into suppurating sinuses and buboes later on.
  • Concomitant genital ulcer refers to genital ulcer that is present along with inguinal lymphadenopathy (Bubo) in the patient.
  • Concomitant genital ulcer is seen associated with Chancroid but absent in LGV. (Option D)

 

Differentiating features between Herpes genitalis & Chancroid:

 

 

 

First line treatment for Chancroid is azithromycin 1g orally as a single dose or ceftriaxone 250 mg IM as a single dose. (Option B)

 

The second-line options for chancroid are as follows:

 

  • Ciprofloxacin 500 mg orally twice a day for 3 days (OR)
  • Erythromycin base 500 mg orally four times a day for 7 days

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • In Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, multiple painful ulcers can occur, including "kissing ulcers," and effective first-line treatment includes Azithromycin 1g orally as a single dose.
  • Concomitant genital ulcer is seen associated with Chancroid.

 

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 30 Page no 30.21

 

Online Resource: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/chancroid?source=search_result&search=chancroid&selectedTitle=1~47

choices.text: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection
Syphilis (Primary Stage)
Chancroid (Soft chancre)
Donovanosis (Granuloma inguinale)

questions.text: A 40-year-old sexually active male presents to an STD clinic with painful genital sores as shown in the image below. He reports that the lesion appeared about two weeks ago and has been progressively worsening. On examination, you observe multiple painful bleeding ulcers with unilateral unilocular painful suppurative inguinal bubo. There are no other visible lesions, and the patient denies any systemic symptoms. He had multiple sexual partners in recent months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chancroid (Soft chancre)

 

OPTION C:

 

Chancroid (Soft chancre):

 

  • Chancroid is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. It presents with painful genital ulcers and painful suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo), as described in the scenario.
  • The ulcers are often described as "soft" (as opposed to the "hard" chancre of syphilis) and can bleed easily.
  • This fits the patient's presentation perfectly.

 

Explanation:

 

OPTION A: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection:

 

  • HSV typically presents as painful vesicles that can rupture to form ulcers.
  • The key difference is that the inguinal lymphadenopathy seen in HSV (if present) is typically bilateral and not as dramatically painful or suppurative as that in chancroid.

 

Differentiating features between Herpes genitalis & Chancroid:
 

 

  • Moreover, the course of the lesion and the presence of multiple painful ulcers fit chancroid better than HSV.

 

OPTION B: Syphilis (Primary Stage):

 

  • The primary lesion of syphilis is the chancre, which is a solitary, painless ulcer with a clean base and indurated borders.
  • The patient's presentation of multiple painful ulcers with a painful inguinal bubo does not fit the primary syphilis picture.

 

OPTION D: Donovanosis (Granuloma inguinale):

 

  • Caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, donovanosis typically presents as painless, beefy-red ulcers that bleed easily. They can progress to cause destruction of genital tissue.
  • While there are similarities in the ulcer presentation between chancroid and donovanosis, the painful and suppurative inguinal bubo described in the case is more characteristic of chancroid.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a sexually active individual with painful genital sores, multiple painful bleeding ulcers, and a unilateral unilocular painful suppurative inguinal bubo, the most likely diagnosis is Chancroid.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 30 Page no 30.21

Online Resource: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/chancroid?source=search_result&search=chancroid&selectedTitle=1~47

choices.text: 1 & 2 only are correct
1, 2 & 3 only are correct
ALL are correct
3 & 4 only are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following are true about chancroid?

 

  1. School of fish appearance
  2. Bleeds on touch
  3. Painful ulcer
  4. Grooves sign
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 & 3 only are correct

 

Option B: 1, 2 & 3 only are correct

 

Explanation:

 

Chancroid: It is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. It is characterized by painful ulcers on the genitalia and swelling of the inguinal lymph nodes. Here are the characteristics based on the given options:

 

  1. School of fish appearance: This term is typically used to describe the Gram stain appearance of Haemophilus ducreyi, where the bacteria appear in a parallel arrangement resembling a "school of fish."



     
  2. Bleeds on touch: Chancroid ulcers can be very tender and may bleed when touched or during cleaning.
  3. Painful ulcer: A defining feature of chancroid is that the ulcer is painful, which is in contrast to the painless ulcer typically seen in syphilis.
  4. Groove sign: The groove sign is classically associated with lymphogranuloma venereum, not chancroid. It refers to the presence of a groove between two swollen lymph nodes, usually in the inguinal area.

 

The correct answer is:

 

Option B: 1, 2 & 3 only are correct

 

  • This is because the first three features are indicative of chancroid.
  • The fourth feature, the groove sign, is not associated with chancroid and is instead associated with another condition, lymphogranuloma venereum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The diagnosis of chancroid is based on the presence of a painful genital ulcer and tender suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy, with the causative agent Haemophilus ducreyi potentially giving a "school of fish" appearance on Gram stain.

 

Ref: Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, chapter 19 Page no 342

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 30.20

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1463

choices.text: Only 1 & 2 are correct.
Only 1 & 4 are correct.
Only 2 & 3 are correct.
Only 3 & 4 are correct.

questions.text:
Which among the following presents with painful genital ulcers?

 

  1. Hemophilus ducreyi
  2. Neisseria gonorrhea
  3. Chlamydia trachomatis
  4. Herpes simplex virus
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Only 1 & 4 are correct.

 

Option B: Only 1 & 4 are correct

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Hemophilus ducreyi is the causative agent of chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful genital ulcers.
  2. Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes gonorrhea, which typically presents with urethritis in men and may be asymptomatic or cause cervicitis in women. It does not typically cause painful genital ulcers.
  3. Chlamydia trachomatis causes chlamydia, which can result in cervicitis in women and urethritis in men, but like gonorrhea, it is not typically associated with painful genital ulcers.
  4. Herpes simplex virus causes genital herpes, which is characterized by painful genital ulcers or blisters.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When evaluating a patient for sexually transmitted infections, it is crucial to differentiate between organisms that cause painful genital ulcers such as Hemophilus ducreyi (chancroid) and Herpes simplex virus (genital herpes), and those that do not typically cause such ulcers like Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • Accurate diagnosis is essential for effective treatment and prevention of transmission.

 

Ref: Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 771

 

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 25.20

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1400, 1463

choices.text: 1-b, 2-c, 3-a
1-b, 2-d, 3-a
1-d, 2-c, 3-b
1-d, 2-c, 3-a

questions.text: Match the Genital ulcer disease in Column A with its clinical presentation in Column B.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

Option A:

 

Explanation:

The correct matches:

1. Donovanosis (Granuloma inguinale)à Presentation: b. Lymphadenopathy absent

  • Donovanosis is a bacterial infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis.
  • It presents beefy red ulcers that bleed easily on contact.
  • The key feature is the absence of lymphadenopathy, distinguishing it from other causes of genital ulcers.

 

2. Hard Chancre (Primary syphilis)àPresentation: c. Painless genital ulcer

  • The chancre of primary syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is typically a single, firm, round, and painless ulcer.
  • It is the hallmark of the initial stage of syphilis.

 

3. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) àPresentation: a. Transient / Absent Genital Ulcer

  • LGV is a sexually transmitted infection caused by specific serovars of Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • The primary lesion may be a transient, painless ulcer or papule that often goes unnoticed, hence patient might not give history of a genital ulcer.
  • The secondary stage is characterized by significant inguinal and/or femoral lymphadenopathy, which can be painful.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Donovanosis presents with painless genital ulcer but without any inguinal lymphadenopathy, Hard chancre from syphilis are painless ulcers, and LGV often presents with Transient and painless ulcer but with lymphadenopathy.

 

Ref: Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 771

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 30.1-30.25

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1463-1467

choices.text: Treponema pallidum
Haemophilus ducreyi
Herpes Simplex Virus
Chlamydia trachomatis

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to your clinic complaining of a painful genital ulcer that developed 5 days ago. He reports multiple unprotected sexual encounters in the past six months. On examination, the ulcer on the glans penis is non-indurated with undermined, sloughed edges. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Haemophilus ducreyi

 

Option B. Haemophilus ducreyi

 

  • The clinical presentation of a painful, non-indurated genital ulcer with undermined edges in a sexually active individual is most indicative of chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • This causes chancroid, a sexually transmitted infection characterized by painful, non-indurated ulcers with undermined edges.

 

 

  • Description of Chancroid: Multiple Ulcers, Necrotic ulcer, Painful, Bleeds on touch, Non-indurated (Opposite to that of Syphilitic Ulcer)
  • This presentation aligns well with the patient's symptoms, making it the most probable diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Treponema pallidum

 

  • This is the causative agent of syphilis.
  • Primary syphilis typically presents with a painless, indurated ulcer known as a chancre.
  • The description of a painful, non-indurated ulcer does not fit the classic presentation of primary syphilis.

 

Option C: Herpes Simplex Virus

 

  • It typically causes painful genital ulcers, but these are often multiple, vesicular, or pustular rather than a single ulcer with undermined edges.

 

Option D: Chlamydia trachomatis

 

  • It can lead to lymphogranuloma venereum, which may present with genital ulcers.
  • However, the ulcers in this condition are typically transient and may not be as pronounced as in the case described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of a painful, non-indurated genital ulcer with undermined edges in a sexually active individual is most indicative of chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

 

Ref:  Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 340

 

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 30.22

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1465

choices.text: Treponema pallidum
Haemophilus ducreyi
Herpes simplex virus
Chlamydia trachomatis

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with a 2-day history of vulvar pain and dysuria. She reports being sexually active with multiple new partners. On examination, there are grouped, shallow ulcers with surrounding erythema on the left labia minora, and the left inguinal lymph nodes are tender. What is the most likely Etiology of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herpes simplex virus

 

Option C: Herpes simplex virus

 

  • This causes genital herpes, which typically presents with painful, grouped vesicles or ulcers on an erythematous base, often with accompanying tender lymphadenopathy, matching the patient's presentation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Treponema pallidum

Is the causative agent of syphilis. Primary syphilis typically presents with a painless, indurated ulcer known as a chancre, which does not match the patient's presentation of painful, grouped ulcers.

 

Option B: Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, characterized by painful, non-indurated ulcers with ragged edges and soft borders. While this could be consistent with the patient's symptoms, the presence of grouped ulcers is more characteristic of herpes simplex virus.

 

Option D: Chlamydia trachomatis can cause a variety of genital infections, but it is not typically associated with the formation of ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Grouped, shallow, painful genital ulcers with surrounding erythema and tender regional lymphadenopathy are most indicative of a herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Ref:  Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 418

 

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 25.21

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1404

choices.text: Halberstaeder Prowazekii bodies
Henderson Peterson bodies
Multinucleated giant cells
Pund cells

questions.text: A young male presents to the STD clinic with painful lesions over the genitals as shown in the image. What is the most likely microscopic finding of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multinucleated giant cells

 

Option C: Multinucleated giant cells:

 

  • Multinucleated giant cells are a typical finding in herpes simplex virus infection, which is consistent with the vesicular and pustular lesions seen on the genitalia in herpes genitalis, often described as painful.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Halberstaeder Prowazek bodies:

 

  • Halberstaedter Prowazek bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions seen in the conjunctival epithelial cells in the case of chlamydial conjunctivitis, not associated with genital lesions.

 

Option B: Henderson Peterson bodies:

 

  • Henderson-Peterson bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies seen in molluscum contagiosum, which is not typically painful and does not present as the vesicular lesions seen in the image.

 

Option D: Pund cells:

 

  • Tissue smear in Donovanosis may show Greenblatt / Pund cells which are large macrophage / epithelioid cells containing cystic spaces, with nuclei pushed to one side and darkly staining inclusions called Donovan bodies.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The characteristic microscopic finding associated with painful genital vesicles as seen in the image is the presence of multinucleated giant cells, which is indicative of herpes genitalis caused by the herpes simplex virus.

 

Ref: Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 418

 

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 25.21

 

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1404
